Award.AwardTitle: Diakoptic Approach to Modeling and Design of Complex Electromagnetic Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is the development and application of a higher order diakoptic method for modeling and design of complex electromagnetic systems. The approach is to break a large system into a number of subsystems of arbitrary shapes, solve the individual subsystems independently using well established techniques such as finite-element and moment methods, and obtain linear relations between the coefficients of equivalent current expansions over the boundary surfaces of the subsystems (diakoptic coefficients), which yield the solution to the original problem.

Intellectual Merit: The diakoptic approach provides a general and efficient way to solve a large problem as a linear combination of independent solutions of component problems. In addition to a significant reduction of the computational burden, this approach will allow reducing an unsolvable problem to solvable ones. As a unique feature, component problems will be characterized by their Norton-theorem-like equivalent representations (in the form of diakoptic coefficients). Applications include emerging electromagnetic materials and antenna arrays.

Broader Impacts: The diakoptic approach will provide the engineering community with a general method for solving the most challenging electromagnetic-field problems in a fashion typical for circuit-theory solutions, but with the rigor of Maxwell's equations. It has the long-term potential to transform the way modeling and design of electromagnetic systems is done. Several educational initiatives, fully integrated with the research, include a course around the diakoptic approach and MATLAB exercises for students, outreach, and efforts to further enhance strong participation of underrepresented students in the PI's group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of this project is to develop and implement the proposed diakoptic approach to modeling and design of complex electromagnetic (EM) systems. The diakoptic approach breaks a large and complex EM problem into smaller and simpler ones, solves them completely independently, and finds the solution of the original problem as a linear combination of solutions of component problems (diakoptic subsystems). The method uses explicit linear relations written in matrix form between coefficients in expansions of equivalent electric and magnetic surface currents on boundary surfaces of the subsystems (diakoptic surfaces). The major outcomes of the project can be summarized as follows.

We have developed a new diakoptic method combining the finite element method (FEM) and the method of moments (MoM) for analysis of inhomogeneous anisotropic dielectric and magnetic scatterers in the frequency domain. The method splits the original electromagnetic system into a number of closed-region subsystems containing material complexities, which are analyzed by a FEM technique (FEM diakoptic subsystems), and an open-region subsystem enclosing the FEM subsystems, analyzed by a MoM technique (MoM diakoptic subsystem). In the final system of equations, the only unknowns are the expansion coefficients on diakoptic surfaces. The method implements Lagrange-type generalized curved parametric hexahedral finite elements of arbitrary geometrical-mapping orders, filled with inhomogeneous anisotropic materials with continuous spatial variations of complex relative permittivity and permeability tensors described by Lagrange interpolation polynomials of arbitrary material-representation orders. Higher order hierarchical vector basis functions are used for the approximation of the fields within the finite elements and the currents on generalized curved parametric quadrilateral patches. When compared to conventional approaches – using the MoM and hybrid FEM-MoM techniques and implementing the same type of higher order numerical discretization – the diakoptic approach enables very considerable memory savings and accelerations, while preserving the accuracy of the analysis.

We have developed a novel diakoptic domain-decomposition method for 3-D electromagnetic analysis based on volume integral equation (VIE) modeling of subsystems. The theoretical foundation of the method are the surface and volume equivalence principles, as it combines the VIE and surface integral equation (SIE) formulations, in conjunction with the MoM. The numerical foundation of the method is a hybrid MoM-VIE-SIE solver. Numerical examples have demonstrated that the proposed VSIE-diakoptic method very substantially increases the efficiency of the conventional pure MoM-VIE approach, as well as that the general diakoptic methodology can effectively include VIE-based subsystems.

We have developed several distinctly different higher order FEM, MoM-SIE, and MoM-VIE techniques in both frequency and time domains, and have demonstrated their unique features and advantages.

We have developed and implemented several novel methods for numerical computation of singular, hypersingular, near-singular, and near-hypersingular integrals defined on higher order generalized curved parametric quadrilateral MoM-SIE surface elements based on the singularity extraction and the singularity cancelation approaches. Such integration techniques are critical for accurate and efficient electromagnetic modeling and computation.

We have developed a novel highly efficient and versatile computational electromagnetic technique for full-wave rigorous numerical modeling of 3-D transformation-based metamaterial cloaking structures, and have demonstrated it in analysis of spherical invisibility cloaks. We have demonstrated a novel conformal cubical transformation-based metamaterial invisibility cloak. This research has then led to the development of conformal transformation-based perfectly matched layers (PMLs) for local-type truncations of FEM meshes utilizing higher order, curved, continuously inhomogeneous, anisotropic large locally-conformal finite elements.

We have developed novel fast scalable higher order parallel algorithms for large and complex scattering, radiation, and propagation problems based on the double (geometrical and current-approximation) higher order MoM-SIE modeling in conjunction with a direct solver for dense linear systems using hierarchically semiseparable structures (HSS) and a rank-revealing QR (RRQR) decomposition for the matrix (memory) compression. In addition to being fast, they offer a promise of being memory- and communication-efficient and amenable to extreme-scale parallel computing.

This grant has resulted so far in 57 journal and conference papers.

This project has directly provided research training and development of five Ph.D. graduate students supported by this grant (during different time periods within the project), as well as one postdoctoral fellow and seven REU undergraduate students. One Ph.D. student graduated in 2011, and three more Ph.D. students graduated in 2015. One Ph.D. graduate is an assistant professor at Oregon Institute of Technology, and the other three are conducting research at Intel, HP, and Microsoft, respectively. The project has also furthered the education of students in two advanced level graduate electromagnetics courses and a newly developed computational electromagnetics course taught by the PI.

All five graduate students supported by this grant belong to underrepresented groups of students in engineering (female students).
